reviewText:
It really hurts me to give this game a bad review, but I must vote with my conscience.  This is a very poor port that needed some extra time before it was released.

First thing I noticed, HORRIBLE sound quality, like nails on a chalkboard. The original SNES version did not suffer from this problem.  Even worse is the ridiculously low max resolution.  How is it that a new update is released that allows people to play KOTOR 2 at 1920 by 1080, and this game is locked at a maximum of 1368 by 768?  This is not 2004, Square, this is embarrasing.

In my opinion, the graphics are an upgrade compared to the SNES version, but on the whole, this is a techincal flop.  Also has an issue screen tearing, which Square claims can be fixed with anti aliasing, but this option is not available at release.  I knew I really should have taken a wait and see approach, given Square's hit and miss history with past ports, but come on, this is freaking Final Fantasy 6.  Should have been a no brainer.  If they just took a direct port of the SNES version, and changed absolutely nothing, it would have been worth the price.  Sadly, they chose to make a bad port of a bad port of a mobile version.  Fans have been worried that was the lazy approach, and they were absolutely right.

The one good thing is there is no additional hidden DRM like they tried to sneak past gamers on past ports.  The ability to rebind keyboard controls is also a good thing.  However, it's just not enough to recommend this game.  Such a shame, but it looks like it's back to using an emulator for me if I ever want to experience this masterpiece as it was meant to be seen.

This is the very first game where I requested a refund.  If these issues are fixed, I'll buy it again.  Until then, praise be to Gabe Newell for introducing the refund policy to protect us from games such as this overpriced, lazy, and frankly embarrasing downgrade of a classic.

reviewText:
Final Fantasy 6 is among my favorite games. However this port, remake, whatever you want to call it, is the worst way to experience it.

- Initially had always-online DRM. This has been patched out; good. But should never have happened in the first place.

- The already abysmal mobile interface is ported wholesale to PC with little optimization, with buttons and scroll bars in place of more thoughtful, less obtrusive, less eyesore layouts. It's as bad on the eyes as it is on the hands, and the one good idea behind the battle UI -- everyone's menus on screen at once, Chrono Trigger style -- suffers as a result.

- Dancing Mad, the final battle theme, used to smoothly transition between its various tiers as the fight progressed. Now, each tier of music just abruptly interrupts the last. In a game known for its stellar music, no less.

- The in-game Album
date:
which acts as the story log/chronicle, has events that are missable (#26, if you don't nab it in the World of Balance), and doesn't respect your decisions and party choices (it acts as though Mog was first met in the World of Ruin; the screenshots mostly just show Celes, Edgar, Sabin, and Setzer despite who you tend to use).

- The multiplayer feature present in the SNES original is gone.

- Configuring controls must be done through a launcher; the in-game options menu has no controller configuration. And if you accidentally unplug or power down your controller during play, well, that's a restart.

- Various long-known, long-outstanding bugs from the original SNES release are still present. Though admittedly, some are addressed, such as Physical Evade actually working and Cyan's Bushido (SwdTech) actually working as intended (pick a skill, he charges as other party members act).

- If you set your movement to WASD, the keys register as part of a new character's name when you try to save, preventing you from naming ANYONE their default name.

- Intermittent freezing/crashing, sometimes from controllers, sometimes not.

- Ill-thought-out visual remastering, with mismatching styles and overall poor quality, including a mixed bag of new sprites and hilariously bad spell effects (compare Flare Star and Forsaken/Goner to their originals, or even the poor GBA versions...).

Square Enix has said they charge more for their games because they deliver better experiences. Many of their games prove this rhetoric thoroughly false, though perhaps none more so than the Steam version of Final Fantasy 6.

Very disappointing.

It's a shame to see a game like Final Fantasy VI handled so poorly.  What could have been a great addition to the Steam library is nothing more than a lazy version of a mobile port with zero effort put into it.

reviewText:
Final Fantasy VIDeveloper: Square-Enix
Publisher: Square-Enix

Introduction
==========
Final Fantasy VI is known far and wide as one of the best classic RPGs of all time. Originally released on the SNES under the title Final Fantasy III, it still holds up to this day as one of the best RPG experiences fans of the genre can have. Despite some minor subjective graphical complaints and some very annoying bugs, I consider the Steam release as one of the better ones. The GBA version was great, but the audio quality and poor translation brought it down. It added some extra content as well, which is also present in the Steam version (The Dragon's Den and Soul Shrine).

Gameplay
==========
There's not much to say here, but I will anyway. Final Fantasy VI is your standard, turn-based RPG, but with a few twists. This entry in the series introduces the Magicite System. When you progress far enough in the story (early on, don't worry), you are given access to powerful stones called Magicite. When equipped, Magicite allows your characters to learn spells at varying rates and also summon powerful creatures known as Espers. Different Magicites teach different spells, and some teach them faster than others. After battles, you earn Magic Points. Once you get enough Magic Points towards a spell (multiplied by the spell's teach rate), you learn the spell. Once a character learns a spell from a Magicite, they keep it permanently. Magicite also grant small bonuses when the character levels up, such as a +1 bonus to Strength, or even a +50% bonus to HP. As long as you teach your characters some basic spells (like Cure, Protect, Haste, Fire, Blizzard, etc), you shouldn't have too much trouble with most fights. Bosses and other challenges will require a bit more strategy.

Final Fantasy VI features 14 recruitable characters, and they are all very unique. Each one has a special ability or command that only they can use. Just to give a few examples: Celes has an ability called Runic, which allows her to absorb spells cast at the party through her sword and restore her MP. Think of it as a magic lightning rod. Shadow can throw consumable items and weapons for big damage. Sabin utilizes special Blitz techniques that require specific inputs that feel like commands from a fighting game. Edgar has a small handful of powerful Tools with different effects. Truly excelling at this game requires you to find the few characters you like that mesh well together. Any party setup works, but some are much better than others.

While each character has their own unique traits, they also have their flaws. I'd like to point out that one big flaw with the character Cyan in the original release was actually fixed in this version! Before, when using his Bushido technique, a bar would appear and fill up to wherever you stopped it. When this occured, you could not do anything else while the bar filled up, effectively grinding your battle to a halt until it finished. In this version, you choose which technique you want the bar to go up to and the game will put that bar over Cyan's status window in the background and allow you to continue inputting commands for other characters until it fills up! As for the other characters, there was nothing that big, but others are not so obvious. For example, you'd think Sabin's Blitz techniques would get stronger as his Strength stat went higher, right? WRONG, most of them are modified by his Magic stat! Umaro, a character you get late in the game, is 100% uncontrollable. One specifical character CANNOT equip Magicite and their stats are fairly average, so you are stuck relying on equipment to make them useable. Despite these flaws, the flexibility of the Magicite System and the number of characters you can use allows you to build your party however you like, so that you can either bolster strengths or cover weaknesses.

Graphics
==========
The biggest complaints I've seen over this version of the game are the sprites and how it has a certain filter used on them to makes them look blurry. One can simply look at the screenshots on the Store Page and decide if they like them or not before buying if this is your main concern (it shouldn't be >.>). I found them to be quite detailed, and stuck to the original designs of the characters pretty well. After you play for a few hours, you'll most likely forget all about the complaints and just enjoy the game.

Another complaint is the battle UI. While this version was originally released on iOS, and it worked there, it's somewhat odd on PC. There are a couple of options in the Config menu to help alleviate these complaints, just find the setting that works best for you.

Sound and Music
==========
The soundtrack of a game is one of the first things I tend to get attached to while playing. Final Fantasy VI has a stellar soundtrack, and every track fits perfectly to each situation. Many of the tracks from this game are considered to be iconic for the entire gaming industry, such as Terra's Theme. Nobuo Uematsu has always been considered a legend for his work on Final Fantasy, and his masterful arrangements of these tunes are nothing less than perfection. Here is a favorite of mine:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bq_Qf3mVnCo

Performance
==========
My PC specs are on my profile. I did not experience any problems running this game. No frame drops or anything. There have been complaints about save files being lost, game-breaking glitches, and other things, but I did not experience any of these. Hopefully you won't either!

I played the entire game using a Logitech F310 controller with no problem. Plugged it in and it worked wonderfully.

Final Thoughts
==========
One of the most memorable and iconic RPGs ever created has made it's way to Steam and it definitely holds up all these years later. Fans of the genre and of Final Fantasy would be hard-pressed to find a better classic RPG experience anywhere. If you are an RPG fan and have not played this gem, I urge you to do so!

Gameplay Demo
==========
https://youtu.be/5j2exuHT5DY

Nerd House Verdict:
==========
Highly Recommended

Be sure to check out Nerd House Gaming for more reviews!

reviewText:
This review is mostly going to be a comparison between this version and the original SNES version of the game.

Pros:
All the enemy and background graphics have been remade and look really awesome.
All of the major characters have their own portraits that show up next to their name when they're talking and it's pretty neat.
You can select other character's moves while Cyan is charging his Bushido. Seems like a small change, but it actually makes Cyan a much better character.
The interface is, in my opinion, better than the original version of the game. In particular, equipping espers is significantly easier to do.
The story and music are just as good as the original game.
Controller support
Achievements and Trading Cards
Runs smoothly at 60 FPS
Cons:
Fixed the Evade bug (RIP Force Armor).
The character sprites look a bit more cartoony than they did in the original game. This is the point that people seem to bring up the most when they give this game a negative review. While I'm not a big fan of them, it doesn't seem like that big of a deal to me, and it doesn't really detract from the overall quality of the game.
Occasionally the game would lock up for a few seconds. While annoying, this bug was rare and didn't cause any actual harm to the game.
Limited display options, basically the only thing that you can change is the resolution. That being said, I don't really feel like a lot of options are necessary for a game like this.
Honestly, I'm not really sure why people hate on this version of the game so much. Other than the one bug I mentioned in my list of Cons, I never had any technical issues playing the game. I played the original FF6 first and loved it, but I still feel like the steam version improves upon it in virtually every way. If you like JRPGs, this is one that I definitely recommend.

reviewText:
I'm a huge fan of the older Final Fantasy games and Final Fantasy 6 is by far my favorite for its diverse, fleshed out characters and rich story. I've owned and played through the SNES cartridge a few times, played it on the Playstation's Final Fantasy Anthology and I've played the GBA version as well.

If the changes to the artwork and sprites are too jarring for you then I wouldn't recommend this game.

If that doesn't bother you, I would recommend this game on its own merit of functionality (I have had absolutely zero bugs or problems with it) and content.  I don't consider myself a purist and the odd choice of character sprites that seem to clash with the other artwork of the game do not bother me that much. Fundamental changes aren't made to the gameplay with exception to the UI but it's easy to get used to on the default setting (tab settings are made for touch screens) and the auto fight feature more than makes up for that. It also keeps the original SNES music but it's been tweaked to give it a higher quality sound (this is a good thing).

People have reported problems with controllers not working and the game not supporting some HD resolutions. I've had no problems using my rock candy xbox 360 controller and since I use an old 19 inch CRT monitor, HD resolutions are lost on me anyway.

As a gamer who grew up with the original I'm not going to say this game is better but I can understand where people who hate on it are coming from. This game, in its own right, is solid and IMHO a welcomed experience for fans who want more of this entry in the franchise. Far from perfect and far from my idea of a definitive version, for what it is I do recommend it.

reviewText:
Final Fantasy VI was the last installment of the Super Nintendo/Super Famicom era of Final Fantasy titles. Released originally back in 1994, the Steam version of this fantastic classic has gone through some upgrades to make the game more suitable for the current era. It should be noted that this version is a mobile port, and was original released for iOS and Android.

The short and sweet of Final Fantasy VI is this: There was a war, called the War of the Magi, that left the earth in shambles. Magic was all but gone, but you play as a girl named Terra who is able to use magic. Turns out she's half Esper, which are what the summons are called in this entry. The world has been rebuilt over hundreds of years since the war, and it's done so in a pretty steam punk fashion. The main villain, Kefka, dresses almost like a clown and is seeking to destroy the world yet again; of course, it's up to you to stop him. Lots of stuff happens, people die, and you learn the backstory for almost every character that you come across; there are 14 in total, all with their own unique quirks and personality.

The main issue that I have with this entry into the Final Fantasy Franchise is that while the story starts off promising and interesting, it devolves overtime to many of the characters lamenting over past mistakes and grievances. There's little in the way of plot development with Kefka other than knowing he wants to destroy everything, and that he's a deceptive little jerk. Of course, the characters at the end finally snap out of their morose attitude when they make amends with the past, but a good chunk of the game is based around this; and by that, I would say roughly 10 hours of the 30 hour story. The story also turns into the typical good vs evil" and "lesson learning" stuff that RPGs are made of.

reviewText:
I'll admit, I haven't played beyond the Rapids in this version of the game, and I've played more on my Kindle than on Steam so far.  But, here goes.
I first played this game as FFIII on the SNES.  Yeah.  For weeks, I would rent it from the movie store over the weekend when I was young, and honestly...I was too stupid to get very far.  I mean, I was usually stuck within the first few hours of the game.  I didn't know I had to meet Edgar, or what I was doing.  I thought I had to get Cider to an old man before someone else gave it to him...  It was a mess.  A lot of the time, I would open someone else's save file further on just to see what else was coming up.  But I fell in Love.  I loved the character art, the music, everything.
When I was a few years older, this came out as FFVI in Final Fantasy Anthology for the PlayStation.  I bought it and a guide, and was able to have the FULL experience finally.  I played this game SO much, and re-played, and beat it as well as finding all the secrets I could.  It was magical.  From Edgar's relationship with Sabin (something reminding me of a friendship I had at the time), to Locke's past with Rachel, to Shadow's mysterious past and speculations about whether or not Gogo is Setzer's Daryl, I was hooked.  The story didn't dwell too long on words.  We saw flashbacks, heard music, and were drawn in.
One of the best aspects was the variety of characters.  Yeah, it can be overwhelming for some people.  To me, it added personality, and bridged the gap between the era of FF games where you made a party (or just had the same small group all game), and where you were forced to always have the Main character on the team.  Earlier in the game, it makes you experience gameplay with All the characters.  You get a feel for them.  Then, World of Ruin.  Find as many of the old members as you feel like, and choose who you want your party to be.  Do you prefer strength?  Sabin, Edgar, Cyan and whoever!  Are you a magic-user?  Relm, Terra, Celes and Strago!  Mixed party?  Edgar, Locke, Mog and Gau maybe!  And best of all, the Espers allowed you to have stat bonuses as you leveled up.  You want that magic user to have stronger magic?  Alright.  You want her to be able to make stronger Physical attacks?  Can do.
It was fun, versatile, and never seemed to force emotion on me.  No offense FF7, but FF6 made me cry more with small parts involving side characters and how they impacted our main characters than you ever did by killing off a main party member.  I still cry sometimes just listening to Rachel Forever, adrenaline pumps when I hear the overworld theme, and I still get chills hearing the song from the Phantom Train.
With newer graphics, an updated combat system allowing for speedy battles, and polishing all around, this really is the re-make I have been waiting for.  It's not just a port of the American FFIII" with a new title background calling it FFVI.  This is a second chance for a true classic to work its way into Your heart if you were too young to have known what a Super Nintendo was.

reviewText:
When FFVI first released on Steam, I was close to refunding it because of numerous gamebreaking bugs. Fortunately, the developer acted quickly and I was able to continue and didn't encounter another bug in the whole 33 hour playthrough.

Despite being widely regarded as one of the best games in the series, I had never played more than a couple of hours of FFVI before starting it on PC.

There were many complaints by members of the Steam community when this game launched, such as the character sprites being those of the recent mobile console refreshes, as well as the game interface itself. I can't say that I had any trouble with either of these points during my story playthrough. The game interface is surprisingly easy to control with an Xbox One controller, and the character sprites were well animated. I'd never played the game with the older SNES sprites, so can't comment on that.

The game's soundtrack is excellent, and with the exception of VII, is my favourite of any game in the series. Each character and area has their own instantly recognisable theme, which is always well suited to their visual design, which is definitely more steampunk in setting than the medievil games which proceeded it, or the sci-fi settings of VII and VIII.

The characters have plenty of depth and each, even the optional characters, have fully fleshed out and explorable back-stories. I'd even say that I prefer the lead villain in VI to Sephiroth from VII, because he provides quite a lot of humour to the story. reviewText:
A truly epic game re-released with a classy update.  I mean this too.  I first played Final Fantasy '3' on SNES when I was 14 years old, and have re-played the game every few years since.  It is like a favourite book that one returns to again and again.  I realise that some folks wanted this game to have been completely redone in 3D and voice acted, but frankly that would simply have destroyed it.  This game got exactly what it needed.  A touch-up.  It's rough graphics, sound, and translation are smoothed out.  A few handy features have been added to make it more accessable.  And that's it.  All they did was wax a classic car, which is what they should have done.  You don't put modern mag-wheels and jam a spoiler on a '55 corvette no matter how much you think it will add to the ride.  Same thing.  So whatever all the nay-sayers are throwing out about this, it is a faithful reproduction of an exceptional game.

Thoughts as follows:

The graphics were gorgeous in their original 16-bit, and they have been carefully touched up to look even better in this version.   This is not a simple video filter, as anyone who has ever played this on an emulator like zsnes should pick up instantly.
The Character sprites do not look out of place, they just look different than they used to and they do look better.
The addition of the original art profiles to the dialogue is actually very nice and adds character without spoiling ones own visualization of the characters as a 3D rendering could have.
The Score is enhanced and cleaned up from the old SNES midis and sounds much closer to the original instrumental score, released  on cd in 1994.
The translation is touched up and some of the more ridiculous and confusing moments in the original release make more sense.  No change to substance whatever.
The only two gameplay tweaks, auto-battle and quick-save, ease the playability by taking away some of the pain of grinding and eliminating classic frustration with the great old glitch/power outage, 'holy xxxx, i haven't saved in an hour' moment. All without changing the gameplay in any substantiveway.

only complaints:

Naming fail.  stupid error that I trust will be rectified with a patch, but you can't use 'wasd' for arrow keys without adding 'd' to the end when naming character.  Hardly a game-breaker though as all you have to do is use your arrow keys for 'abxy' and use backspace to eliminate the addition before accepting.

A few glitches - game has stopped a couple of times in about 8 hours of play, as expected in any new release.  happily though, every time I was able to start where it froze by virtue of the game auto-quicksaving with each room change. So you just hit continue when you reload and start where it froze.

All in all the game is more beautiful, more enjoyable, and gently tweaked rather than sullied by 'upgrades' that would have cheapend this fine game like coca-cola in a glass of Bowmore's 15 year old 'Darkest'.

Happy to spend the price of a mediocre bottle of wine on this well-cellared gem.

If you're unsure of the new art work, I recommend giving this version a chance anyways. I played through the original (titled Final Fantasy 3 in the US) dozens of times in the 90's and this new coat of paint makes it feel like a fresh experience again. It's impossible to replace the nostalgia I have for this game and it's original sprites, but most of the new art work quickly grew on me. There are a few illogical issues with the control scheme. For example, when you select a spell in battle, you first choose from the White, Black, or Grey schools of magic. If you choose black magic and then decide you want to cast a white or grey spell instead, you can't just switch to them. Instead you have to cancel out of the menu, choose magic again, and then choose the school you want to cast a spell from. This can be a problem if you're using Active Time Battle and don't already know what spell you're going to cast. Also, while you are selecting a target, up and down chooses an enemy from a list as expected, but pressing left or right switches the character you are controlling instead of changing your target from the enemy list to the party list. To switch between the 2 sides, you press square instead (using a PS4 controller).

This game runs at 60 fps, unlike Final Fantasy V on Steam, which is strangely capped at 30 fps.

There are a few improvements compared to the original version. When inputing a Blitz with Sabin, you can now see which buttons have been recognized before confirming. I just want you to know the joy that is Final Fantasy VI, my favorite game in the series. If you haven't played it, this isn't the wrong choice, necessarily. I recommend this only because it's a legal way to play the game if you don't have access to any other, and it's an alternative that is perfectly passable. However you experience Final Fantasy VI is up to you, but this port does have a lot of serious design issues among other problems. This would be my last recommendation on which version of this game to play (ignoring the mobile one, which this is a port from), but no matter what, this is still Final Fantasy VI. Here is my extended opinion:


Why this port sucks     Ugly and clashing sprite and menu redesign: Sprites are muddy and lack the character of the originals from the SNES, in my opinion. The second part could be debated, but I think it's clear that not a lot of effort went into these sprites when compared to the likes of the Final Fantasy 1, 2, and 4 remakes on the PSP. The menu design I'll get into below, but how it looks really clashes with the art design of the game. It looks like iOS design from 5 years ago -- big bubbles with the little shininess on them. Not steampunk in the slightest.

reviewText:
OK, first off, I am not one of those purists that will take pixels over smooth any day. I actually like this art style. I don't think they needed to smooth them out though, but then again, it isn't really an issue. I have played practically every version of this game, including the original Japanese Super Famicom one, translated by Sky Render. Everyone I know pretty much agrees that the SNES and GBA versions were the best, especially if you hack the GBA ROM to insert the original Super Famicom/SNES audio. Square Enix ported that version to iOS and Android, sprucing up the graphics and using the original SNES audio. Towns and castles on the world map are now 3D models. The character sprites have been smoothed, and the portraits appear in the dialogue box. The menus had been changed to reflect the touch screen interface, and this version retains that same look, unfortunately. The gamepad controls are the same as the smartphone version, with the option to have a scrolling battle menu or tabs. I played it on my NVIDIA Shield, so I already knew the controls. The script appears to be the same as the GBA version with some minor tweaks. The new features that were added to the GBA version appeared in the smartphone port, and are present in this port as well, so we have the extra dungeons and bosses to look forward to. Another addition to the smartphone port was achievements, which are present in the Steam version, too.

Final Fantasy VI is probably my favorite of the series. As I stated, I have played every version of it, even the PS1 port with loading times. Ugh. So of course I bought this version. What are the pros and cons? Well, for the pros, you get a classic RPG with a decent length, great story and characters, and fun gameplay. It has a great customization system, where each character not only has their own specific class and abilities, but they can ALL learn magic spells (except for two, one of which doesn't need to learn them, as you'll see). Each party member can equip different weapons, and two relics apiece, which can greatly improve abilities and stats. The story is fairly basic, nothing too complex, but that's what gives it its charm. There are a total of 14 characters to recruit, each with their own strengths and weaknesses. And of coiurse, there's an airship or two. And chocobos and Moogles.

The cons? Well, nothing major. My only gripes with this port is are minor ones, but glaringly noticeable at first. First, the game is NOT widescreen. It initially starts in a windowed mode, though Alt+Enter maximizes it. However, like the Final Fantasy V port, there are black bars on each side. This is something that irritated me about the smartphone port. Initially, the game was widescreen, taking up almost the whole screen on my HTC M8, but with an update, they added bars on the side, with the time and a battery indicator. Not necessary. by any means. And for some reason, they did it to FFV, too. And thus the Steam ports have black bars. No idea why they weren't able to fix that.
Second, the interface is clunky. Huge. And it bothers me that once again, Square Enix couldn't be bothered to at least scale it down for a bigger screen. Of course, that would require more effort, something they seem to be incapable of with all these ports. At least Lightning Returns got the treatment it deserved, unlike the first two FFXIII games. And FFIII and IV still have gamebreaking bugs, years later. But I digress. A third, but again, minor issue, is that there's slight screen blur when walking around, particularly horizontally. But all three of these issues can be overlooked as once you've played for a half-hour or so, you don't even notice them anymore.

So what is my final verdict? Get this game. Especially if you've never played it before. Buy it on Green Man Gaming right now, and use the voucher code on the home page to knock it down to $12.32. Not bad for a 30+ hour classic.

reviewText:
Final Fantasy 6 on PC!!!! (Need I say more?)

Yes, actually it seems I do need to so here's a few things review-wise:
(please keep in mind that I am comparing legitimate versions of the game, not emulated versions)

1. This game has one of the most memorable and engrossing stories in all of gaming history, so much so that it makes the story of Final Fantasy 7 seem mediocre by comparison.

As a side note, the translation has been tweaked and improved from the GBA version which is always nice to see.

2. The GBA version, has terrible sound quality, this preserves the original SNES sound quality with some modernized improvement tweaks, very pleasent to listen to overall in this steam version. As someone who started playing this when it was still called Final Fantasy III in NA, the only sound that seemed out of place so far were the organs on the intro screen. Whether or not the new organs are good or bad is again, subjective.

3. This modernized version of the game runs smoothly in a comfortable windowed mode, much like emulators would be used to run the older version, there is no real need to full screen it since the art assests are not meant to be blown up that large anyway...

For those of you that DEMAND full screen here's a trick: alt+enter (I know, magic)

On that note it should also be mentioned that the text is very crisp and easy on the eyes in this release compared to  the GBA version or the even older versions.

The updated sprites, in my opinion, fit cleanly into the updated background textures of the world they are in. Also, these new assests add fresh life and color to an old world. Considering they are products of the original sprite designer, they function quite well and do not feel out of place at all within the moving world of the game.

To add to those points, this version is visually a large improvement over the old versions that were made for a SD display. It seems important to remind some people that the original game, being a game made for SD display, will look very distorted and blocky at any resolution higher than 640x480 while this game can reach higher resolutions.

4. The game has full controller support in my experience with no lag and responsive input. Navigating the updated menus works quite well with an analog stick.

Speaking of menus, everything from the battle menu to the inventory menus seem to fit nicely after a few minutes of adjustment seem quite sensible for the functions they are meant to perform.


Ignore the haters, dont pay attention to the nostalgia whiners, this game is worth having and it is a story that will stick with you for a long time to come.

Just remember that it is easier to complain and nitpick than it is to actually make one of these games yourself, but as someone who has played this game since it's original NA release, this is a version worth having considering it does not look like blocks of color at resolutions higher than SD.

:::First thing's first, the bad:::

This is a port of an IOS game, and you can tell.  It's jarring for the first five min or so.

The team making the IOS game stayed as true to the original art style as possible, and that's not going to be a good thing for some people.  The characters arms are all freakishly long, for example, and there's sections in the game where in the original there were some graphical design mistakes, and for whatever reason these mistakes are still here and since it's been cleaned up they are more noticeable

You'll notice some slowdown occasionally, which is odd considering how small a game this is.

:::Now, the good stuff:::

It's freaking FF6!!!! It's one of the best in the series.

Once you actually get used to the menu system it's more functional than the original game's menu system.

MUCH appreciated balance tweaks, the biggest I've noticed so far being Cyan's sword arts.  In every other release so far you were not able to issue commands to your party while his sword arts charged, and the baddies would swing on you, which made him by far and wide the absolute worst character in the game.  Now you can issue commands to your party while he charges his moves.

So I have put in an hour into the FF6 remake.

First impressions:

The graphics are cute. There are lovely battle effects for Terra's magic and I think the sprites are growing on me. The music is the same classic soundtrack, which is always lovely, and I LOVE THE PORTRAITS.

The meat of any RPG is the battle system, so let me tell you about it. There are these windows that represent a character on the bottom and when the window reaches all the way up, then that character can have an action from their list. You guys know that every character in the game has their own unique commands, right? At first it was just weird, but once I got the hang of it, I found it very fast to navigate! I am playing with a keyboard until I get a Xbox controller, which I am not used to, but once I learned all the commands, I was happy with it.

It does not go full screen. I don't care about that, most of the time I play in window mode to easily navigate what else I might need on the computer. There is no start up thing like in other Steam FF games, either, and I don't mind. I had to figure out all the commands until I reached the Adventurer's school, but at that point everything was explained.

The text is almost the same. Some parts are translated better, but some parts are word for word what we had on the SNES and PSX Anthology versions. I love this story a lot and I'm looking forward to collecting all the achievements!

Buy? ♥♥♥♥ YES BUY. I'm glad I got it.

Well what can I say?  Probably one of the most loved RPG's from the SNES era, finally, released on PC.  So....am I going to say anything that matters?  If you are like me you saw this game and just shoved a handfull of bills at your screen before you realized you need to use your credit card to buy this.  Look, if you have fond memories of this and don't own it on SNES you will probably buy this.....or maybe you have it on the PSx, or an emulator.....well I have it on emulator, PSx and (unfortunately not SNES) now on my PC.    Over my life I have probably paid for this game more times than any other....and you know....I never regreted it once.

So the good.
+SNES style music and sound are intact.
+ITS ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ FFVI!
+Graphics look nice and smooth, the update is subtle and really fits in the style nice, it still looks like the game I remember with a bit of gloss, which honestly.....is all I would have wanted.

The Bad
-I swear the SNES version controlled better, it is minor since movement isnt a big deal in these kind of games it still seems.....strangely delayed, but possibly only a second or so, just enough to feel weird w/o being a real big problem.
-The menus are actually less user friendly, honestly again a minor problem but ....it can be frustrating, for example I equip a new sword.....I stay in that characters sword menu, meaning I need to back out and select the helm slot and equip that, then back out......just annoys me on a personal level. Look my complaints are minor and I already love this game again, I saw it today, I bought it today, loaded it up right away and it is actually still open in the other window.  I'm currently trying to figure out how late I can play before I need to sleep for work tomorrow....my complaints are minor and really.....let us be honest with eachother, if you're like me....you'll buy it, no matter what....we've been waiting for this a long time and honestly, I love that they kept the SNES sound effects and music....I will be enjoying this for a long time.
